Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: yeah, that was my workaround, but it adds a ton of overhead (comparatively speaking, when compared to the rpc response having more detail)

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Yes that helps, but the low level design of the CC_EVAL function means that it cannt send the data to JSON return in its current form.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: CC_EVAL either returns a txid or ""

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: and it pushes the reason for the fail to stderr

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Maybe there is a way to push it via another path, so it can be accessed by the RPC return fucntion

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The RPC could maybe check as many contitions as possible before trying CC_EVAL ?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: and onyl very edge cases then return an ambigious error

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: maybe we need `dicewhyfail` similar to `dicestatus`?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The RPCs I have been working, on have like 2x more code checkiung all inputs before calling any functions, so it cna return an error first.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: that seems the easiest way, but adds a LOT of code overhead inside the daemon

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Either way it needs to be somewhere

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I found using the C++ code inisde the daemon to sort data and return is liek 100x faster than caling multiple RPCs though

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: and sorting / filtering via dAPP

Content:
`I found using the C++ code inisde the daemon to sort data and return is liek 100x faster than caling multiple RPCs though`
right, which is why even though it 'adds a LOT of code overhead inside the daemon', it's still a better option than processing overhead client-side, imo

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
being me for a moment:
The fact that s/k/znomp exists and anyone can throw up a pool in 7 minutes sometimes creates its own issues in that pool ops don't "need" to know what they are doing
Just because we *can* throw up 100 pools doesn't mean that we have even one *stable* pool
